channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Were Moved and Hidden as U.S. Sought Them, Filing Suggests
item.description: The filing by the Justice Department paints the clearest picture to date of its efforts to retrieve documents from the former president’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Department of Justice
item.media:description: The Justice Department included a photo of documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home in its court filing.

item.title: US Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
item.description: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting American Indian and Native Alaskan communities particularly hard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Shannon Stapleton/Reuters
item.media:description: A patient who died of Covid was removed from an I.C.U. in Cleveland, Ohio.

item.title: Mikhail Gorbachev, Who Oversaw the End of the Soviet Union, Is Dead at 91
item.description: Adopting principles of glasnost and perestroika, he weighed the legacy of seven decades of Communist rule and set a new course, presiding over the end of the Cold War and the dissolution of the U.S.S.R.
item.dc:creator: Marilyn Berger
item.media:credit: Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev had a profound effect on his time: In little more than six tumultuous years, he lifted the Iron Curtain, transforming the map of Europe and the political climate of the world.

item.title: With War in Ukraine, Putin Tries to Unravel Gorbachev’s Legacy
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin calls the end of the Soviet Union a “genuine tragedy” for Russia, and he blamed Mikhail S. Gorbachev for bending to the demands of a treacherous and duplicitous West.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Vladimir Rodionov/ITAR-TASS, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2000.

item.title: A Reporter’s Memories of Gorbachev, and That Pizza Hut Commercial
item.description: Anatoly Kurmanaev, a New York Times reporter, recalls a childhood forever changed by a man with a distinctive birthmark.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Vassili Korneyev/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow in 1991.

item.title: Russia’s Occupation of Nuclear Plant Gives Moscow a New Way to Intimidate
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears to be using the facility to scare Ukraine’s leaders and warn the West to stay out of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians say that the shelling near Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia power plant is coming from Ukrainian forces, and Ukraine’s government insists that Russian forces are responsible.

item.title: Russia Halts Natural Gas Flows to Germany Again
item.description: Gazprom said the Nord Stream 1 pipeline would undergo three days of maintenance, raising worries about a complete shutdown of Russian gas deliveries to Germany.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:credit: Annegret Hilse/Reuters
item.media:description: Part of the Nord Stream 1 pipeline in Lubmin, Germany.

item.title: How an Afghan Soccer Player Escaped the Taliban and Began a New Life
item.description: How an Afghan soccer player and her teammates fled their homes, outran a murderous regime and forged the uncertain beginnings of a new life.
item.dc:creator: Juliet Macur
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: Fati checking herself in a mirror before a game. Her height — 5 feet 8 inches — is an asset as a goalkeeper.

item.title: Pain, Fear, Stigma: What People Who Survived Monkeypox Want You to Know
item.description: Seven patients share their stories of devastating symptoms, frustration over finding care and their efforts to help each other when doctors and officials have failed.
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack, Joseph Goldstein, Sharon Otterman and Justin J Wee
item.media:credit: Justin J Wee for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. Will Set Aside Monkeypox Vaccines in New Equity Program
item.description: White House officials said an “equity intervention pilot” will get more doses to communities that have been left behind in the nation’s inoculation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble/Reuters
item.media:description: A monkeypox vaccination in Tucson, Ariz., this month. A new program the White House announced Tuesday is aimed at increasing access to the shots.

item.title: Doug Mastriano’s Extremely Online Rise to Republicans’ Governor Nominee in Pa.
item.description: The G.O.P. candidate for governor of Pennsylvania deftly used Facebook to build a loyal right-wing fan base at the height of the pandemic. Will it be enough to win a competitive general election?
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although Doug Mastriano is perhaps better known for challenging the results of the 2020 presidential election, he built a loyal following with pandemic livestreams on Facebook.

item.title: Naomi Osaka, Serena Williams and One Last Shared U.S. Open
item.description: Osaka lost in the first round Tuesday to Danielle Collins, but would remember the final Grand Slam of the year for the front-row seat she had to her idol’s farewell party.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Futterman
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Naomi Osaka lost her first-round match to Danielle Collins in straight sets.

item.title: For Venus and Serena Williams at the U.S. Open, Day and Night Experiences
item.description: Unlike her sister, Venus was not prepared to deal with questions about her tennis future after a loss in the first round of the singles tournament. “I’m just focused on the doubles,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Venus Williams lost in the first round to Alison Van Uytvanck of Belgium in straight sets.

item.title: Serena Williams’s Next Opponent Is a Struggling Anett Kontaveit
item.description: They will face off in a packed Arthur Ashe Stadium on Wednesday, a venue that feels like home to Williams even if it has not always been a haven.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Jerry Lai/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: Anett Kontaveit will face Serena Williams for the first time in the second round at the U.S. Open.

item.title: Buy Now, Pay Later: Going Into Debt for Groceries
item.description: Americans are increasingly turning to “buy now, pay later” services for food and other everyday essentials. And there are signs that the practice is putting some in deep debt.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Chona Kasinger for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Buy now, pay later” services, which allow consumers to pay for goods in installments, often without interest, have become increasingly common for food purchases.

item.title: Why Totino’s Needs 25 Ways to Make Pizza Rolls
item.description: As supply chain delays and rising costs made individual ingredients harder to procure, food companies had to become very flexible.
item.dc:creator: Julie Creswell
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pulling apart a cheesy pizza roll at Ingredion, which tests recipes with substitute ingredients for clients.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Reaches 9.1 Percent, Driven by Prices for Energy and Food
item.description: The rate, a fresh record, came as nine countries registered double-digit inflation in the year through August.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Heat, Water, Fire: How Climate Change Is Transforming the Pacific Crest Trail
item.description: The already grueling 2,600-mile hike now includes the added challenges of global warming, which can mean a lack of shade and exposure to smoke and fire.
item.dc:creator: Rowan Moore Gerety and Mason Trinca
item.media:description: Thru-hikers on the Pacific Crest Trail spend up to five months walking from Mexico to Canada — and the imprint of climate change is now felt along the entire route.

item.title: Ashley Judd: The Right to Keep Private Pain Private
item.description: I could not help my mother, Naomi Judd, who lost a long battle against mental illness. I can, however, do something about how she is remembered.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Judd
item.media:credit: Gaiamoments/iStock, via Getty Images Plus

item.title: Ron DeSantis Is a Test Case
item.description: The DeSantis governorship provides insight into what our national life might look like if, in 2024, Republicans win a clean sweep.
item.dc:creator: Thomas B. Edsall
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times

item.title: The Anti-Abortion Movement Is Gunning for Fetal Personhood
item.description: Despite clear political headwinds, the movement has embraced a push for fetal personhood.
item.dc:creator: Mary Ziegler
item.category: Dobbs v Jackson Women's Health Organization (Supreme Court Decision)

item.title: This Is the Other Way That History Ends
item.description: A once-scholarly discipline courts irrelevance in its desperate bid for relevance.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Why Many Americans Turned on Anthony Fauci
item.description: A science worth following must lead.
item.dc:creator: Ari Schulman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; photograph by Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: The Decline in American Life Expectancy Is Not Inevitable
item.description: Public health is at a crossroads.
item.dc:creator: Dave A. Chokshi
item.media:credit: Gabriel Alcala

item.title: Jackie Chan Is Making a Movie in Syria. That’s a Problem.
item.description: The only trouble is, it’s not the real one.
item.dc:creator: Leila Al-Shami
item.media:credit: Louai Beshara/Agence France-Presse, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Actors on a set of the Chinese film “Home Operation,” in Hajar al-Aswad, a Syrian suburb destroyed by the al-Assad regime.

item.title: Europe’s Gonna Party Like It’s 1979
item.description: Sometimes you just can’t let markets rip.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times

item.title: Our Latest Covid Poll
item.description: Americans on the left end of the political spectrum have become less anxious about Covid.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Times Square in July.

item.title: The Parkland Students, Four Years Later
item.description: We look back at conversations with some of the survivors of the 2018 shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
item.dc:creator: Clare Toeniskoetter, Sydney Harper, Lisa Tobin, Anita Badejo and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stones placed on a memorial garden at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School to honor victims of the Parkland shooting.

item.title: Where to Host Your Birthday in NYC
item.description: Here’s where to host a group birthday dinner, whether it’s a park hang or an all-out fete.
item.dc:creator: Becky Hughes
item.media:credit: An Rong Xu for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nothing screams “festivities” quite like a Dungeness crab on a lazy susan (especially this one at Wu’s Wonton King).

item.title: Beefcake, Goethe’s Boswell and the Greeks
item.description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
item.dc:creator: Molly Young

item.title: Mexico’s Leader Vowed ‘Hugs Not Bullets,’ but the Carnage Continues
item.description: The president disbanded the Federal Police and created the National Guard to tackle soaring violence, but three years later, criminal cartels have expanded their reach.
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard providing security at a crime scene in Celaya last week.

item.title: Some Carmakers Say Recycling Car Parts Is the Future. But Is It Realistic?
item.description: “Circular manufacturing” has the promise to reduce waste by reusing parts to make new cars. There are glimmers of hope, but they are currently outweighed by challenges.
item.dc:creator: Roy Furchgott
item.media:credit: Matt Williams

item.title: Silicon Valley Discovers an Age-Old Child Care Hack: The Neighbors
item.description: Otter, a new child care platform, is attracting millions of dollars in venture capital. But can it fix a broken industry?
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Helen Mayer became a stay-at-home parent to her twin boys, Arthur, left, and Andrew, during the pandemic. Her struggles to find child care inspired her to start Otter.

item.title: West Point Has a K.K.K. Plaque Mounted Above Entrance to Science Hall
item.description: A special congressional commission that recommends the removal of Confederate symbols at U.S. military sites flagged the bronze plaque in a new report.
item.dc:creator: Hurubie Meko
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mykhaylo Palinchak, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The U.S. Military Academy at West Point. A congressional panel flagged a plaque mounted at the entrance of Bartlett Hall Science Center that includes an image of a hooded figure and the words “Ku Klux Klan.”

item.title: More Children Are Swallowing Batteries and Landing in the E.R.
item.description: Twice as many kids needed treatment after putting button batteries in their mouths, noses and ears compared with the previous decade, a new study says. Here’s how to prevent it, and what to do if it happens.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Why Chosen Families are Important for L.G.B.T.Q. People
item.description: For L.G.B.T.Q. people, the bonds between friends can be liberating and transformative. Five of these close-knit communities tell their stories.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Dividing Divorced Parents
item.description: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Charlotte Fu

item.title: Feeling Ambivalent About Motherhood Is Normal
item.description: After years of engaging with parenthood from a distance, it’s time for a psychiatrist specializing in women’s mental health to take her own advice.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Lakshmin, M.D.
item.media:credit: Lilli Carré

item.title: Kids Are Using Social Media More Than Ever, Study Finds
item.description: The report highlights a 17 percent increase in screen use among teens and tweens in the last two years — more than in the four years prior.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: A Star Maestro, Fighting Brain Cancer, Finds Peace in Music
item.description: Michael Tilson Thomas, who returned to Tanglewood, where his career first took off, refuses to be confined by his illness.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Lauren Lancaster for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael Tilson Thomas rehearsing with the Boston Symphony Orchestra at Tanglewood on Saturday.
